Summarize (Orchestrating the Discussion)

Discussing Solutions and Strategies

You can start the Summarize after all have finished exploring What If...? Situation B. Those who finish What If...? Situation B before others can work on What If...? Situation C and help lead the discussion for those who did not get to it.

  • Begin by having students share how they used the table of ratios to answer the questions about the cosots for different numbers of boxes. Seeing the various ways others use multiplicative reasoning can enhance each student's flexibility to reason with ratios. (Language)
  • Teaching Aid 2.2: Selling Cupcakes Ratio Table can be used as needed to illustrate ideas from students.
    • How can you use the table to find the cost for 20 boxes?
Answers will vary. See some possible strategies that follow.

Strategy 1

Students double the 10 boxes to get 20 boxes and double the prices of $120 to $240.

This is scaling the ratio using multiplicative reasoning. This is one example of finding equivalent ratios using proportional reasoning.

Strategy 2

Students find the cost for 1 box using division. Then they multiply the number of boxes by 20 and the cost by 20.

This is unit rate reasoning that will be made more explicit in Investigation 3.

Strategy 3

Students add the 5 boxes and the 25 boxes together to get 20 boxes. Then they ass the $60 ad the $180 together to get $240 for the 20 boxes.

While students might think of this as addition, we can also look at the reasoning using the Distributive Proprty. Five of the 12-dollar boxes and 15 of the 12-dollar boxes is the same as 20 of the 12-dfollar boxes. 5($12) + 15($12) = 20($12)

Suggested Questions

  • How are the strategies that we have seen alike?

Push for students to see the similarity in the multiplicative reasoning. For example, if a student in you class uses strategies like those shown, you can ask about the operational thinking.

  • If we take a look at Strategy 1, we can see that the group multiplied the quantities in the ratios by 2. In Strategy 2, the group divided by 10 and multiplied by 20. What happens to a quantity if you divide by 10 and multiply by 20?
  • In Strategy 3, if we take 5 of something and we take 15 of something, is that the same as taking 20 of something?
  • How can the table of ratios be used to find other ratios and answer questions?

• It is the same as multiplying by 2. 20 รท 10 = 2.
  • Yes. This is like the area problems in Number Connections, but now we are using money. 5(the cost of a box) + 15(the cost of a box) = 20(the cost of a box).
  • Answers will vary. Some students may see the table as a way to organize equivalent ratios. Some students may see the table as a visual representation that helps them "make jumps" (reason multiplicatively) to find other equivalent ratios.

Making the Mathematics Explicit

Students will use unit rate to find values in the table, write the equations, and analyze the graphs. However, the vocabulary of unit rate is not introduced unit Investigation 3. (Time) This gives students time to focus on the connections to the concepts in Variables and Patterns in this problem.

Encourage students to connect the reasoning that they did in Variables and Patterns to the table of ratios. Ask questions to assess how students are connecting the reasoning in the table of raios to the equation and graph representations.

Suggested Questions

  • What are the variables involved in this relationship?
  • On your table, how can you find the total amount of money collected for any number of large boxes sold?
  • What operation is in you equation? Why?
  • How can you use your equation to find costs not on your table?
  • How can you use your equation to find other equivalent ratios?
  • How are graphs helpful to show the relationships represented in the ratio tables?

• The variables are number of large boxes sold and total amount of money collected.
  • Students may mention strategies like those previously shown. Also, the amount of money is equal to 12 times the number of boxes sold. Or for Cameron, the amount of money collected for the small boxes is equal to 8.5 times the number of boxes sold.
  • Multiplication. We have been using factors and multiples, which is multiplicative reasoning.
  • Use the equation to find more quantities of boxes and the amount collected for those boxes.
  • The graph helps to show the pattern in the table and equation. The increase in the amount collected is shown. As the number of boxes increases by 1, the amount collected increases by $12 for the large box. As the number o boxes increases by 1, the amount collected increases by $8.50 for the small box.
For What If...? Situation C, discuss the use of a ratio table, an equation, and a graph to find the amount of money Cameron needs to collect for N boxes of cupcakes.

Now What Do Students Know?

Ask students to reflect on the discussion and answer the Now What Do You Know? Questions.

See answers to the problem for more information about the strategies and embedded mathematics.

Reflecting on Student Learning

Use the following questions to assess student understanding at the end of the lesson.

  • What evidence do I have that students understand the Now What Do You Know? Question?
    • Where did my students get stuck?
    • What strategies did they use?
    • What breakthroughs did my students have today?
  • How will I use this to plan for tomorrow? For the next time I teach this lesson?
  • Where will I have the opportunity to reinforce these ideas as I continue through this unit? The next unit?
